summary: Morris and others test the plausibility of widespread reports that African elephants (Loxodonta africana) get intoxicated from the ethanol found in the fermented fruit of the marula tree (Sclerocarya birrea). Extrapolating from human physiology, they find that elephants would have to consume nothing but fermented marula fruits at an abnormally high rate to become inebriated. Coupled with elephants' preference for fresh fruit, they conclude this is unlikely. The authors suggest other substances in marula trees may be responsible for elephant intoxication, such as the high vitamin content of fresh fruits or the poisonous beetle larvae found in the bark.
title: Myth, Marula, and Elephant: An Assessment of Voluntary Ethanol Intoxication of the African Elephant (Loxodonta africana) Following Feeding on the Fruit of the Marula Tree (Sclerocarya birrea)

summary: Rohland and colleagues analyze the nuclear DNA of the three living elephant species, woolly mammoths (Mammuthus primigenius), and for the first time, American mastodons (Mammut americanum). They find that bush and forest elephants are distinct species as genetically distant from each other as Asian elephants are from mammoths, and that the latter two are sister taxa.
title: Genomic DNA Sequences from Mastodon and Woolly Mammoth Reveal Deep Speciation of Forest and Savanna Elephants

notes:
• The published body mass equation for "Grade II – Grade IV" female African bush elephants (Loxodonta africana) on Table 7 is incorrect, it should read 1.88 × 10−3 × SH2.569.
  • The published body mass equation for "young – Grade I" Asian elephants (Elephas maximus) on Table 7 is incorrect, it should read 3.32 × 10−4 × SH2.903 (A. Larramendi, personal communication, 8 January 2020).
summary: Larramendi estimates the life sizes of 161 proboscidean specimens from 51 species, providing detailed statistics for 11 well-known species. He uses the Graphic Double Integration (GDI) volumetric method to calculate body mass, and develops new equations to calculate shoulder height. Notable specimens include fossils of Palaeoloxodon namadicus that Larramendi estimates to have been larger than Paraceratherium, an extinct rhino genus formerly considered the largest land mammal, and the skeleton of Jumbo.
title: Shoulder height, body mass and shape of proboscideans

title: Elephants get drunk because they can’t metabolize alcohol like us

contributors: Mareike C. Janiak (co-author); Swellan L. Pinto (co-author); Gwen Duytschaever (co-author); Matthew A. Carrigan (co-author); Amanda D. Melin (co-author)
summary: Janiak and colleagues identify and analyze the gene ADH7 in 79 mammal species. They find that African elephants (Loxodonta africana), Asian elephants (Elephas maximus), and woolly mammoths (Mammuthus primigenius) possess a mutated version that can no longer produce functional alcohol dehydrogenase class IV (ADH IV), an enzyme that metabolizes ethanol. This implies these species have a low alcohol tolerance and lends credence to rumors that elephants inebriate themselves on fermented fruits, which Morris et al., 2006 deemed unlikely when extrapolating from human physiology.
title: Genetic evidence of widespread variation in ethanol metabolism among mammals: revisiting the ‘myth' of natural intoxication

title: Million-year-old DNA provides a glimpse of mammoth evolution

contributors: Tom van der Valk (co-author); Patrícia Pečnerová (co-author); David Díez-del-Molino (co-author); Anders Bergström (co-author); Jonas Oppenheimer (co-author); Stefanie Hartmann (co-author); Georgios Xenikoudakis (co-author); Jessica A. Thomas (co-author); Marianne Dehasque (co-author); Ekin Sağlıcan (co-author); Fatma Rabia Fidan (co-author); Ian Barnes (co-author); Shanlin Liu (co-author); Mehmet Somel (co-author); Peter D. Heintzman (co-author); Pavel Nikolskiy (co-author); Beth Shapiro (co-author); Pontus Skoglund (co-author); Michael Hofreiter (co-author); Adrian M. Lister (co-author); Anders Götherström (co-author); Love Dalén (co-author); Gloria Cuenca-Bescós (reviewer); David Lambert (reviewer); Krishna Veeramah (reviewer)
links:
• From publisher (DOI: 10.1038/s41586-021-03224-9)
  • From eScholarship
  • From METU Biological Sciences
  • From Munin
  • From DiVA
  • From Europe PMC
  • From PubMed Central
  • From Gwern.net
summary: van der Valk and others extract DNA from three Siberian mammoth molars, dubbed Krestovka, Adycha, and Chukochya. Using biostratigraphy and molecular dating, the authors conclude Krestovka and Adycha are over a million years old, making their DNA the oldest ever sequenced. Adycha and Chukochya are classified as ancestral woolly mammoths (Mammuthus primigenius) and are found to have adaptations to the cold previously thought to have arisen later. Krestovka resembles a steppe mammoth (M. trogontherii), but genomic analyses suggest it belongs to an unknown mammoth lineage, possibly a new species. Phylogenetic comparisons indicate Columbian mammoths (M. columbi) arose from interbreeding between woolly mammoths and the Krestovka lineage.
title: Million-year-old DNA sheds light on the genomic history of mammoths

title: A mammoth contribution to ancient genomics

summary: Schulz and peers investigate inhalation in the trunk of a captive female African elephant (Loxodonta africana). They present her with differently sized food items and observe she can grab them by applying suction, a behavior previously thought to be exclusive to fish. They also measure the elephant’s nasal cavity with an ultrasonic probe while she is suctioning water, and find she can drastically increase her trunk’s volume by contracting its inner muscles. From this, the authors calculate that elephants are able to inhale faster than humans sneeze.
title: Suction feeding by elephants
